all_paragraphs: In data science, metrics are juicy. The results from big data can give us seductive quantitative insights that we can use to improve our business. Metrics make us more aware — the more we are “checking in” on something, the more we can observe change over time. Metrics motivate us — it gives us something to “shoot” for. Metrics offer the binary of accomplishment or failure — if we measure up to an established goal, then we succeed. Otherwise, we fail.
In business, metrics are used all the time. Metrics provide measurements about a particular process and provide a basis on which to improve, or “optimize” on. Some metrics include:

Clearly, metrics matter. They play an important role in our lives and in business. They offer quantitative measurements that we can use to “track” our progress. But sometimes, metrics can be toxic. Sometimes, the metrics that we target to guide decision-making end up hurting us more than they help us.
Charles Goodhart, an English economist, wrote what we know today as Goodhart’s Law. The theory states:
Any observed statistical regularity will tend to collapse once pressure is placed upon it for control purposes.
“When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.”

Let’s break this down. The first part of the line reads, “When a measure becomes a target…” So for a certain metric being tracked — a bar is set as a goal for people to meet. The second half of the line reads, “…it ceases to be a good measure.” Once people know that a reward awaits if the goal is met, then they will adjust their efforts to achieve the goal, even if the overall outcome for the business is bad.

A simple example of Goodhart’s Law is the CEO trying to maximize profit for his/her company. A data scientist finds a relationship between increased pay and employee performance. The data scientist then provides this insight to the CEO. Taking the data scientist’s advice, the CEO incentivizes higher employee performance by offering a bonus only to people who meet a certain metric. All of the employees want the bonus, so the metric set by the CEO becomes the priority and everyone adjusts their habits at work accordingly. But Goodhart’s Law tells us that this plan may backfire on the CEO, which would reflect poorly on the data scientist who provided the insight. When providing insights, data scientists must be mindful of unforeseen consequences that may result from targeted metrics.
“Incentive structures work…So you have to be very careful of what you incent people to do, because various incentive structures create all sorts of consequences that you can’t anticipate.”

Let’s say that in a boutique cupcake shop, the owner wants to increase profit. The shop has so many customers that they need to bake more cupcakes than they normally can per day. The owner knows that the demand is there and needs to increase efficiency somehow. She doesn’t have quite enough money to hire more bakers, so she decides to make her existing bakers more productive through a tantalizing monetary incentive — an extra $100 to the baker who bakes the most cupcakes at end of each week. Naturally, each baker wants the money and makes their “cupcake count” the highest priority. So throughout the first week of the incentive plan, customers are streaming in, the bakers are working furiously, and there are always plenty of cupcakes to buy. At the end of the week, the owner checks the books and notices that the profit went up. The owner is thrilled — it looks like the plan worked!

However, when she checks her phone, the owner notices that the bakery got a lot of very negative reviews on Yelp over the past couple of days. Some customers complained about goopy, undercooked cupcakes — with raw egg in them. Some complained that the icing and decoration on top were messy. Others griped about rude customer service and “feeling rushed” when trying to order and pay. Furthermore, when the owner checks in with her bakers, she notices that they look very tired. She also sees lots of burn marks on their hands and forearms. Upon giving the $100 incentive to the winning baker, a colleague baker hands his apron to the owner and resigns. He says that he doesn’t feel safe working here and claims that the winning baker intentionally “sabotaged” one of his bakes, just to win the bonus. As the weeks go by, more and more negative Yelp reviews hurt customer volume and in just a few weeks, the cupcake shop goes bankrupt.

What once was a high-end cupcake boutique with happy, cooperative bakers crafting high-quality cupcakes, has suddenly produced frantic, backstabbing bakers with cupcake quantity as their only guiding principle. Cupcake quality, customer satisfaction, and employee satisfaction all plummeted. The business suffers multiple unforeseen consequences and ultimately fails as a result of metric incentivizing.

While this example is a bit dramatic, it illustrates that metrics can be extremely useful, but also disastrous if we are over-focused on them. When a business obsesses over a metric, then other qualities of the business that may not be measured, but are perceivable, can be unintentionally sacrificed.

So let’s go back to the cupcake shop example. The owner wanted to make some more profit and determined that the number of cupcakes produced per baker was the metric to live and die by. But how about other subtler, but equally important qualities that ensured her business’s success? What about the happiness of her bakers? What about the level of cooperation between her bakers? What about the safety of her bakers? These were underpinning qualities of the bakery’s work culture that kept the business strong, stable, and successful, which really should be the goal at the end of the day.

So in the context of Goodhart’s Law, we can say that short-term business metrics such as monthly profit goals, the total number of hours worked by employees, and the total number of cupcakes baked, only serve a finite mindset. At its most basic level, measurement should provide a sense or feeling of progress. Through their work, people just want to feel that they are making progress and are advancing a cause that they care about. Businesses should recognize this.

In “The Infinite Game” Simon Sinek talks about business as a game that has no beginning and no end. A business can either play the game or stop playing when they are out of resources or are unwilling to continue playing. Sinek argues that good businesses understand that there is no “winning” or “losing”. In the infinite game, there are only businesses in the game and businesses that are not. In this vein, the author suggests that businesses should have an overarching mindset to be sustainable, flexible, and enduring, to continue “playing the game.” This is opposed to being a business that obsesses over short-term metrics, beating their competition, and constantly racing to “win” in the short-term.

“…to succeed in the Infinite Game of business, we have to stop thinking about who wins or who’s the best and start thinking about how to build organizations that are strong enough and healthy enough to stay in the game for many generations to come.” -Simon Sinek, The Infinite Game

Indeed, metrics matter for data scientists and businesses. However, we must be aware of the temptation of metrics. It isn’t all about hitting the profit target. It isn’t all about optimizing productivity. It isn’t all about being “number one” and beating out all of your competitors. For businesses, it’s about staying in the game for as long as you can.
